- Definitions and methods differ: “Tree” counts depend on how a tree is defined, detection limits, and modeling. The tree estimate combines diverse datasets and has uncertainty. The Milky Way star count depends on how faint stars, stellar remnants, and substellar objects are treated and also has uncertainty.
- Time and scope: Tree numbers change with deforestation/reforestation. Star counts are essentially constant on human timescales. Also the claim usually compares trees on Earth to stars in just our galaxy; comparing to the entire observable universe would flip the result (far more stars than trees).
- Messaging: The raw numeric comparison is correct under common estimates, but the statement can be misleading if readers assume both numbers are equally precise or if they mean “stars in the universe.”

- Verdict: True (with caveats) — Current estimates put ~3 trillion trees on Earth versus roughly 100–400 billion stars in the Milky Way, but both figures are estimates that depend on definitions and methods.
